messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] possible reproduction tsuba with sekigane
messages.msgSnippet: I agree with Curran.  One alone looks fake, but four of them with the same symptoms leaves me little room for doubt. Jim Repro, Repro, Interesting (but I m
messages.messageBody:
I agree with Curran. One alone looks fake, but four of them with the same "symptoms" leaves me little room for doubt.

Jim



Repro, Repro, Interesting (but I'm still thinking
Repro), and a Repro.

Funny interior measurements, unevenness of sukashi
along the outer circumfrence of the tsuba, and other
odd things that default me into thinking 'repros' on
all. The same sort of funny stuff appears to my eye on
all of them.
But I wonder how they were made. My feeling is
originals are used. If so, and it is simply some fault
of measuring the originals, then it follows the next
generation could be very convincing.

Maybe Peter is right and they are just very
overcleaned, but I vote 'repros'.

Curran



[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] possible reproduction tsuba with sekigane
messages.msgSnippet: In a message dated 6/20/2005 5:14:31 P.M. Central Daylight Time, ikkanshi@westnet.com.au writes: repo I  think, I have seen these before. dude, tsuba are
messages.messageBody:
In a message dated 6/20/2005 5:14:31 P.M. Central Daylight Time,
ikkanshi@... writes:

repo I think, I have seen these before.




dude,
tsuba are seldom " one of a kind ".................
I recalled a tsuami tsuba that appeared in some expert's home
page..............lo and behold, i HAD the same one too !!

The only way one can kantei those tsuba is to have them in hands. Color etc
can be manipulated by some " photo-shop " softwares, yes ?

milt

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] possible reproduction tsuba with sekigane
messages.msgSnippet: I agree with Curran - they don t look right, and would vote for modern copies rather than overcleaned and/or repatinated  originals. rkg (Richard George) ...
messages.messageBody:
I agree with Curran - they don't look right, and would vote for modern
copies rather than overcleaned
and/or repatinated originals.

rkg
(Richard George)
